organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

title.gco:CharacterString: 100-Meter Resolution Natural Earth of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: These data were downloaded from the National Atlas website (http://www.nationalatlas.gov/atlasftp.html) in August 2014.

collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States of America, 1997-2014

abstract.gco:CharacterString: This lsyer is a georeferenced raster image containing a natural-earth image of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The image is land cover in natural colors combined with shaded relief, which produces a naturalistic rendition of the Earth's surface. These data are in an Albers Equal-Area Conic projection. The Natural Earth data were produced from existing National Atlas land cover, tree canopy, elevation, and satellite view data. This layer is part of the 1997-2014 edition National Atlas of the United States.

purpose.gco:CharacterString: The 100-meter resolution Natural Earth data were developed to portray the terrain and land cover of the United States at 1:1,000,000 scale. They are intended primarily for visual purposes. The original NLCD data or Landsat Thematic Mapper imagery data should be used for conducting scientific analysis, and the original NED data should be used for determining the most accurate elevation values. No responsibility is assumed by the National Atlas of the United States in the use of these data.

credit.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States. (2013). 100-Meter Resolution Natural Earth of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/sn039yv2317.

useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the U.S. Geological Survey regarding the utility of the data on any other system, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. No responsibility is assumed by the U.S. Geological Survey in the use of these data.

otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: This item is in the public domain.

title.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States of America, 1997-2014

supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: Included with the GeoTIFF are an information file (.xml), an auxiliary information file (.aux.xml), an image overview file (.ovr), a .tfw file (more information included below), and a .prj file (more information included below.) The contents of the associated world file (.tfw) are: >100.0 >0.0 >0.0 >-100.0 >-195950.0 >437950.0 The projection (.prj) file contains the following information: > PROJCS["Albers_NAD83_ PRVI ", >GEOGCS["GCS_North_American_1983", >DATUM["D_North_American_1983", >SPHEROID["GRS_1980",6378137.0,298.257222101]], >PRIMEM["Greenwich",0.0], >UNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]], >PROJECTION["Albers"], >PARAMETER["False_Easting",0.0], >PARAMETER["False_Northing",0.0], >PARAMETER["Central_Meridian",-66.5], >PARAMETER["Standard_Parallel_1",8.0], >PARAMETER["Standard_Parallel_2",18.0], >PARAMETER["Latitude_Of_Origin",15.0], >UNIT["Meter",1.0]] Data set extent in meters (Albers Equal-Area Conic projection) >North 438000 >West -196000 >East 286000 >South 230000 There are no NULL or NODATA values in the GeoTIFF. Instead, all oceans are assigned a RGB color of (193, 224, 250) (blue) and all non-U.S. land is assigned a RGB color of (240, 235, 211) (tan). Information about National Atlas Web services can be found on the Web Map and Web Feature Services page; see <http://nationalatlas.gov/infodocs/webservices.html>.

gml:UnitDefinition.gml:identifier: Unified Code of Units of Measure

measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: No tests for logical consistency have been performed on this map layer.
Data completeness reflects the content of the source data.

description.gco:CharacterString: The Natural Earth image is a combination of land cover in natural colors and shaded relief. The shaded relief part of the image was created from the National Atlas Elevation data. Relief was rendered with Natural Scene Designer Pro 6.0. The original 100-meter data were down-sampled to 200 meters and received one application of smoothing in NSD Pro 6 prior to relief rendering. Light azimuth = 315 degrees, angle = 45 degrees. Relief in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands was rendered with 200 percent vertical exaggeration. Shaded relief was composited in Adobe Photoshop CS6. The Avenza Geographic Imager 4.1 plug-in for Photoshop maintained georeferencing of the shaded relief image. In Photoshop, the relief is composed of four layers that print above land cover: global illumination, high mountain illumination, global shadows, and high mountain shadows. Illumination prints as transparent white, global shadows as transparent black, and high mountain shadows as transparent gray blue. The land cover part of the image was derived from the National Atlas Land Cover, Tree Canopy, and Satellite View data sets. These products were re-colorized and blended in Photoshop to create land cover with natural colors. The Landsat images (satellite view) may appear as subtle textures in cropland and wetland. Using dissolve blending mode in Photoshop for layers containing NLCD forest data (Land Cover and Tree Canopy) created a slightly pebbled surface to mimic a natural forest canopy. To eliminate small urban areas from the image, urban areas were extracted from the Land Cover data set, aggregated, placed on a layer mask in Photoshop, and a 1-pixel Median filter was applied. Inland water bodies were removed from the land cover with Photoshop s content aware fill tool. Manual touch-ups afterwards repaired discordant fill textures. All land cover received 0.7 application of Gaussian blur prior to merging it with the shaded relief. Land cover in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands received slightly more saturation and density than land cover elsewhere to better reflect the vibrant tropical environment. In Puerto Rico, the highly fragmented land cover conflicted with the irregular topography. To alleviate this problem, the contrast of the land cover was reduced in Photoshop by duplicating it on a second layer, applying Gaussian blur (100 pixels) to the duplicated layer, and merging it with the original land cover layer at 50 percent normal opacity. This produced less visually jarring land cover that merged better with the shaded relief. Urban areas were exempt from this treatment.
Ocean areas were assigned a RGB value of (193,224,250) (blue) and non-U.S. land was assigned a value of (240,235,211) (tan).
